qas.question: What was a drawback of early home recording systems?
What was the initial cost range of early recording devices?
What year  was the  Victor Orthophonic Victrola released?
What was the typical weekly pay of a worker in 1925?
What options were available that effected the cost of the Victor Orthophonic Victorla?

context: Electrical recording preceded electrical home reproduction because of the initial <a0_0>high cost<a0_0/> of the new system. In <a2_0>1925<a2_0/>, the Victor company introduced the Victor Orthophonic Victrola, an acoustical record player that was specifically designed to play electrically recorded discs, as part of a line that also included electrically reproducing Electrolas. The acoustical Orthophonics ranged in price from <a1_0>US$95 to US$300<a1_0/>, depending on <a4_0>cabinetry<a4_0/>; by comparison, the cheapest Electrola cost US$650, the price of a new Ford automobile in an era when clerical jobs paid about <a3_0>$20<a3_0/> a week.
